RSO must know two main policies:

 

1.  Cadet Administrative and Training Orders (CATO) direct all activities in the Cadet programs. The main policy controlling air rifle ranges, and rifle storage and transportation is CATO 14-41 Authorized Rifle Training.

Click here for important information on CATO 14-41 and other applicable CATO.

 

CATO 14-41 contains direction on:

 

•Authorization for Cadets and specific adult leaders to fire the air rifle;

 

•Storage requirements for air rifles (also read information about Canadian law below)

 

•Transportation of air rifles; and

 

•Safety rules for an air rifle range.

 

IMPORTANT: the content of this CATO will be assessed on the final exam for this course.

 

2.  Range Standing Orders – every military range will have Standing Orders. The RSO must read these orders before conducting an activity on that range.

Policy

Sea, Air and Army Cadets, Cadet Instructors and qualified Civilian Instructors are authorized to fire the air rifle in the prone and standing positions. The only air rifle that can be used for Cadet training is the .177 cal, Daisy/Avanti Model 853C, NSN 1005-01-389-2310.  

Air rifles must be stored in a sturdy secure container that is kept in a locked room. They must be unloaded and stored separately from pellets.  

An air rifle must be transported unloaded and in a secure container. Drivers who transport an air rifle in a private vehicle must have written authorization from their Regional Cadet Support Unit Commanding Officer.

Critical safety rules are:

 

•personnel must be instructed in safe use of the rifle before firing;

•ranges must be inspected before use;

•the RSO must strictly control access to the range; and

•a first aid kit must be available at the firing point.

 

Air rifles may only be fired on a properly prepared range.

CATO

 

CATO 14-41 - Authorized Rifle Training. Following all the policies contained in CATO 14-41 will demonstrate that you are being reasonable and safe when you use, handle, transport and store the Cadet air rifle.  CATO 14-41 was written to meet the requirements of the Criminal Code as well as all applicable Department of National Defence policies.

 

CATO 12-24 - Reporting Procedures – Injuries. Should a cadet or Civilian Instructor be injured during a range activity, follow the steps in CATO 12-24 to fill in form DND 2299 and to submit it through your chain of command. For CIC members who are injured, refer to DAOD 5018-2.

 

CATO 12-26 - Significant Incident Report (SIR).  Should a serious incident occur (e.g. severe injury, theft, criminal act, etc.), a SIR may need to be initiated. Contact your Commanding Officer to get direction.
